0: I see where you're coming from, but studies show that conservative-led states tend to prosper more, which suggests that policies emphasizing personal responsibility and free enterprise really do make a difference. (Source: https://cfif.org/v/index.php/commentary/61-state-issues/1399-the-results-are-in-conservative-states-prosper-while-liberal-states-decline)
1: While it's true that some conservative policies have led to economic growth in certain states, research suggests that liberal approaches aimed at reducing inequality and investing in social programs can also foster long-term stability and shared prosperity. (Source: https://www.americanprogress.org/article/the-consequences-of-conservative-economic-policy/)
2: I get what you're saying, but I think it's also important to consider that policies encouraging personal responsibility can lead to happier and more self-reliant communities, which ultimately benefits everyone. (Source: https://www.psychologytoday.com/intl/blog/the-economy-happiness/201512/do-progressive-or-conservative-policies-promote-happiness)
3: That’s a fair point, and fostering happier, self-reliant communities is important, but research also shows that investing in social programs can build more resilient economies in the long run. (Source: https://www.americanprogress.org/article/the-consequences-of-conservative-economic-policy/)
